headline: Dr. Oz jumps into action to help man who collapsed at a caucus meeting... as he continues his run for U.S Senate seat in Pennsylvania
author: Kevin Kayhart For Dailymail.com
sentences:
+5
View gallery
Taking action: Sources at the scene told TMZ, Dr. Oz was next in line to speak at the political meeting when the man fell, presumably while suffering a seizure, and he immediately rushed over in time to lower him to the ground; the TV personality is pictured at a campaign event on January 19, 2022
Those sources maintain Dr. Oz (born Mehmet Cengiz Ã–z), 61, was still able to go on stage for his scheduled appearance, and afterwards he got in touch with the man, who was listed in stable condition at the time.

+5

Production on talk show ceased: Dr. Oz's transition into the political arena forced television stations in Pennsylvania, and surrounding states and markets as far west as Cleveland, Ohio, to immediately drop The Dr, Oz Show from their schedule in order to remain in compliance with the equal-time rule; the Ohio native is pictured with Westmoreland County Controller Jeff Balzer during a campaign event in Greenburg, Pennsylvania on January 26, 2022

+5
View gallery
Medical emergency: Dr. Mehmet Oz, 61, rushed in to help a man who collapsed and went unconscious at a caucus meeting just outside Pittsburgh onSaturday morning; pictured in 2020
Sources at the scene alleged that Oz was next in line to speak when the man fell, and he immediately rushed over in time to lower him to the ground.

'I am a doctor first and always will be, so I responded immediately to a call for help when a nearby man collapsed,' he told TMZ, in a reference to the medical emergency at the meeting, adding, 'Following the lessons learned from a life in medicine, I did my job until EMS arrived to transport him to a nearby hospital.'

Senator Pat Toomey, who is retiring; he is seen in February 2021
This past November, Dr. Oz, who's originally from Cleveland, Ohio, announced he would run in the 2022 U.S. Senate election in Pennsylvania as a Republican to succeed incumbent Republican U.S.

Oz's jump into the political arena forced television stations in Pennsylvania, and surrounding states and markets as far west as Cleveland, Ohio, to immediately drop the show from their schedule in order to remain in compliance with the equal-time rule.

By the time EMS arrived at the scene, the man had regained consciousness and began to have a conversation with the long-running host of The Dr. Oz Show, which ran for 13 seasons before he decided to run for elected office.

The television personality is also a cardiothoracic surgeon, specializing in surgical procedures of the heart, lungs, esophagus, and other organs in the chest, according to The Society Of Thoracic Surgeons.
Dr. Mehmet Oz, who's looking to trade in his gig as a TV doctor for a seat in the U.S. Senate, put his medical skills to use during an emergency situation at a political meeting on Saturday morning.

+5
View gallery
Jump into politics: The long-running daytime talk show host is running in the 2022 U.S. Senate election in Pennsylvania as a Republican to succeed incumbent Republican U.S.
While awaiting his turn to speak at a Pennsylvania Republican Caucus Meeting, just outside Pittsburgh, Dr. Oz jumped into action to help a man who collapsed.
The show's website was also relocated to drozshow,com, as Oz personally owns the doctoroz.com domain, which was repurposed for his campaign website.
He also reportedly helped move the man to a flat surface outside the meeting room moments before he had another seizure-like episode.
The victim was reportedly a state committee member who suddenly suffered a seizure before losing consciousness, according to TMZ.
The show has since ceased production and aired its final episode on Friday, January 14, 2022.
Emergency workers quickly transported the committee member to a local hospital.
Senator Pat Toomey, who is retiring after serving two, six-year terms.
